In the context of Y Combinator, the founders wanted to create a platform that would allow them to raise capital for startups without being beholden to the traditional VC model. They started using web apps, not desktop software, and this proved to be a significant advantage in terms of scalability and ease of use. 

However, the founders soon realized that other startups were also using web apps, and this led to a mismatch between the two groups. They also discovered that other startups were using APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) to develop their services, and these were often written in complex and expensive languages. The founders decided to create an alternative to these platforms, a platform for hosting web apps, which they called "Viaweb". This platform allowed them to build and run web apps in the browser, and also provide APIs to the users.

As Y Combinator grew, they noticed that other startups were using their platform and were benefiting from it. They also learned that many PR firms were still relying on traditional media, which was not an effective way to promote their work. They also realized that the early adopters of new technologies were often demanding, eager to see improvements and be added to the community.

To improve efficiency, they focused on having a robust language with good libraries, good implementation, and good documentation. They also wanted to have a book about the language, so that experts could learn about it and improve it. 

The founders realized that the best way to make a language popular was to have it be good for writing throwaway programs. They also wanted to make a library of libraries that would make it easy for developers to write efficient code. They also knew that the number of users per server would be a critical factor in supporting a server-based application.

To find a solution to the problem of time, they wanted to have a fast and efficient language that could run smoothly even when the system is under load. They also wanted to have good support for threads, which is the key feature of most modern operating systems.

Their language, Common Lisp, was good for writing efficient programs, and many experienced developers wanted to use it. However, it was not the most popular language, as it was not a scripting language of the popular systems like Unix, and did not have a good implementation.
